newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Pan Australian says Yilgarn shows good gold.
newsitem.headline: Pan Australian says Yilgarn shows good gold.

text.p: Pan Australian Resources NL said on Thursday that a shallow rotary air blast and reverse circulation drilling programme at its Yilgarn extension project in Western Australia had intersected significant gold mineralisation.
In anomaly E, a 50 metre deep hole had intersected, from a depth of 36 metres, 12 metres at 1.3 grams of gold a tonne, including four metres at 2.7 grams of gold a tonne, it said.
Another hole, 400 metres to the north and along the strike, intersected 16 metres at 0.4 grams of gold a tonne, including four metres at 1.2 grams of gold a tonne, it said.
Managing director Gary Stafford said the results were extremely encouraging, especially when compared with geophysical and geochemical data.
The results and information on file indicated a mineralised trend with a strike length of at least 400 metres with a width of more than 25 metres.
The belt was more extensive than previously interpreted from the company's airborne geophysical data, he said.
Target Zone T26, about 70 kilometres south of Norseman, now contained eight identified anomalies after recent infill soil sampling detected three new anomalies.
Together they represented a discontinuous, anomalous gold zone seven kilometres long and an average 600 metres wide, he said.
